title: Erdős Problem #976: Greatest Prime Divisor of Polynomial Products
description: For an irreducible polynomial f ∈ ℤ[x] of degree d ≥ 2, what is the growth rate of F_f(n) = greatest prime divisor of ∏_{m=1}^n f(m)? The main conjectures (n^{1+c} or n^d growth) remain OPEN, though Tenenbaum (1990) proved F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c).

overview.historicalContext: This problem concerns the distribution of prime factors in values of irreducible polynomials. Nagell and Ricci established the first bound in 1922, showing F_f(n) ≫ n log n. Erdős improved this in 1952 using sieve methods. The problem has connections to algebraic number theory through the splitting of primes in number fields. While Erdős claimed a stronger bound in 1965, the proof was never published and was later found to be flawed. Tenenbaum finally proved the bound F_f(n) ≫ n exp((log n)^c) in 1990, but the main polynomial growth conjectures remain open.
overview.problemStatement: Let f ∈ ℤ[x] be an irreducible polynomial of degree d ≥ 2. Define F_f(n) = max{p prime : p | f(m) for some 1 ≤ m ≤ n}, equivalently the greatest prime divisor of ∏_{m=1}^n f(m). Question: Is F_f(n) ≫ n^{1+c} for some constant c > 0? Or even ≫ n^d?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization presents the known bounds as axioms and defines the main conjectures precisely. The Nagell-Ricci bound uses elementary methods. Erdős's 1952 improvement uses sieve techniques to count integers with large prime factors. Tenenbaum's proof employs sophisticated large sieve inequalities. The algebraic approach relates prime divisors of f(m) to prime splitting in the number field ℚ[x]/(f) via Chebotarev's density theorem.
keyInsights: The degree d of the polynomial should control the growth rate of F_f(n)
Current best bound n·exp((log n)^c) is sub-polynomial but super-linear
The gap between known bounds and conjectures is enormous
Prime distribution in polynomial values connects to algebraic number theory
Sieve methods and large sieve inequalities are the key analytic tools

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Defines irreducible polynomials over ℤ, polynomial degree, greatest prime divisor P(n), and the main function F_f(n) = greatest prime dividing any f(m) for 1 ≤ m ≤ n.

sections.title: Known Lower Bounds
sections.summary: States the three main known lower bounds: Nagell-Ricci (n log n), Erdős 1952 (n(log n)^{log log log n}), and Tenenbaum 1990 (n exp((log n)^c)).

sections.title: Main Conjectures
sections.summary: Formalizes the two open conjectures: polynomial growth F_f(n) ≫ n^{1+c} for some c > 0, and the stronger degree growth F_f(n) ≫ n^d where d = deg(f).

sections.title: Special Cases
sections.summary: Examines special cases including linear polynomials (Dirichlet's theorem), quadratic polynomials (connection to Gaussian primes), x² - 2 (quadratic reciprocity), and cyclotomic polynomials.

sections.title: Proof Techniques
sections.summary: Describes the key proof techniques: sieve methods (Erdős), large sieve inequalities (Tenenbaum), algebraic number theory (prime splitting), and Chebotarev density theorem.

sections.title: Related Functions
sections.summary: Discusses related concepts including the greatest prime factor function P(n), comparison with P(n!), and smoothness of integers.

sections.title: Historical Notes
sections.summary: Historical context including Erdős's unpublished 1965 claim (later found flawed), the Erdős-Schinzel 1990 weaker bound, and Tenenbaum's final resolution of the stronger bound.

sections.title: Summary and Status
sections.summary: Summarizes the complete problem status: known bounds, open conjectures, and the significant gap between current results and conjectured growth rates.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #976 asks about the growth rate of the greatest prime divisor of polynomial products ∏f(m). Tenenbaum (1990) proved F_f(n) ≫ n·exp((log n)^c), but the main conjectures that F_f(n) should grow like n^{1+c} or n^d remain OPEN. The problem lies at the intersection of analytic number theory (sieve methods) and algebraic number theory (prime splitting in number fields).
conclusion.implications: A resolution of the polynomial growth conjecture would have implications for the distribution of prime factors in polynomial sequences and connect to fundamental questions about smooth numbers and the structure of multiplicative functions.
openQuestions: Is F_f(n) ≫ n^{1+c} for some c > 0?
Is F_f(n) ≫ n^d where d = deg(f)?
What is the optimal exponent in the known bound n·exp((log n)^c)?
Can the methods be extended to reducible polynomials?
